page.title: 08Ecology of the Uzmaston area
page.content: From January to March {Curlews}can be seen feeding on the marshes of the Western Cleddau.{Teal,}small European ducks, are in the flood water, while the {Canada Geese}fly in formation. { {Starlings }and {Pigeons}looking for food in farm buildings, are a problem. Late April brings the {Cuckoo,}then { {Magpies, Jackdaws, Rooks, Wrens}and { {Bullfinches.}There are many{Tortoise- {shell Shelducks}and{Herons,}seen on the tide. Musical{Blackbirds}abound with an occasional{Swan}on the river or a{Buzzard}or{Cormorant}in flight. {Curlews}are seen before a storm, with the{Mallards} in the high tide flood afterwards. By the end of the year the song birds ({Robins, Blackbirds, Tits} and{Chaffinches}) are all hungry and eat the hawthorn, cotoneaster and holly berries.{Herons}are roosting and {Swans, Wigeon}and{Teal}are still here.
